repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection contains some restricted material. Restrictions related to specific material are listed in the detailed contents list. This collection may require review before it is available for use. Please contact DCA for further details.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by the Office of Alumni Relations, 2005 -- 2020.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized in fifteen series: Tufts Univesrity Office of Alumni Relations, event files; Tufts University Alumni Assocation and Jackson College Alumni Association; Oral Histories; Photographs and auido-visual materials; Photo Albums; Tufts Univesrity Office of Alumni Relations, Tufts Clubs; Tufts Univesrity Office of Alumni Relations, subject files; Tufts Univesrity Office of Alumni Relationsgive-aways; Secretary of Alumni Assocation, Fred Nickless; Secretary of Alumni Assocoation, Joseph W. Morton; 2017 accessions; 2018 accessions; 2019 accessions; Unprocessed Accessions; and 2020 accessions.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Office of Alumni Relations (1924-present) was established in 1924 by the Tufts University Alumni Association and was administered by Tufts as the Office of the Alumni Secretary. The first Alumni Secretary was Joseph W. Morton A'11, who served from 1924-56. The Secretary handled alumni outreach, conducted fundraising for the Alumni Fund, created alumni directories, edited university publications, assisted with alumni career placement, and coordinated with the Alumni Council and the Tufts University Alumni Association. The Secretary was based in Cousens Gym and, after 1965, in Alumni House. The Office has been located at 80 George St. since 2007.

The office was greatly expanded by President Jean Mayer in 1978 as the Office of Alumni Relations under the direction of Richard A. Kelley A37 G38. The new Office played a crucial role in the "Campaign for Tufts," at the time the largest fundraising initiative in Tufts' history by far. In 1985, the Office's second director, Ronald Brinn A58, created Tuftonia's Day to encourage closer bonds between alumni and the university. The holiday is celebrated in mid-April every year to commemorate the signing of the Tufts charter and has become a global celebration of all things Tufts-related.
The office is administered by the University Advancement Division and overseen by the Senior Vice President for University Advancement as of 2018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Office of Alumni Relations Records, 1850 -- 2019. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processing notes for Secretary of Alumni Assocation, Fred Nickless Series: The original order of committee and chronological correspondence files was maintained; the overall series consisting of Alumni Symposium pamphlets, committee files, correspondence (including staff communication, Sheetz correspondence, and Tredennick correspondence), death reports, and handbooks was arranged alphabetically. Correspondence files were foldered. Committee files were refoldered and possibly relabeled by an unknown staff member. Titles in brackets were assigned by an archivist. The series was processed by Christopher Carr in fall of 2008; supervisor: Susanne Belovari. 2017, 2018, and 2019 accessions were processed by Leah Edelman and Melissa Cepeda in 2017-2019. Materials were placed in archival boxes and loose materials were placed in folders where needed. Received order was maintained. A file and item-level inventory and series-level description were created and the finding aid was updated at the time of processing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains scrapbooks, VHS tapes, U-matic tapes, audio reels and cassette tapes, slides, correspondence, office files, subject files, meeting minutes, event brochures, and memorabilia such as Frisbees and commemorative pens pertaining to alumni activities and relations. This collection also contains photographs of Tufts graduating classes and alumni events, student and alumni directories, and presentations.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. Copyright to all materials created by Tufts University employees in the course of their work is held by the Trustees of Tufts University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains office files relating to the planning of alumni events including Tuftonia Day, Homecoming, and Alumni Parade.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically by event type and chronologically within event.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Some of these images may be in the Digital Library. This poster was found uncatalogued in the stacks in summer 2008. It is located in an oversize folder in the map case. It is an oversize poster with pasted photographs of various Tufts people and activities, some are captioned, some are not. Poster 1: Five Photographs Photograph 1: Campus Art Photograph 2: Uncaptioned [man working on early computer] Photograph 3: Uncaptioned [woman doing art projects with four young children] Photograph 4: Uncaptioned [seven people in a (budget?) meeting] Photograph 5: Dr. C. Stuart Welch, left, co-chairman of the Equipment Fund Campaign, listens attentively to Dr. William E. Browne, vice-president of the Medical Alumni Association. On the right is Harry Blotner, Medical Alumni Secretary-Treasurer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

It is located in an oversize folder in the map case. It is an oversize poster with pasted photographs of various Tufts people and activities, some are captioned, some are not. Poster 2: Five Photographs Photograph 1: WGBH-FM "Massachusetts Viewpoint" November 20, 1963 [Photo includes Sen. Edward Kennedy] Photograph 2: Uncaptioned [man making a toast/speech] Photograph 3: Rick Linde Photograph 4: Uncaptioned [Six women meeting] Photograph 5: Uncaptioned [Fletcher Dorm (Blakeley Hall)]

Poster 5: Five Photographs Photograph 1: Reading Seminars Photograph 2: Uncaptioned [Five students and one adult standing from of sign for the North hall school] Photograph 3: Uncaptioned [Students on bleachers] Photograph 4: Uncaptioned [Ten men in lecture hall (automobile lecture?)] Photograph 5: Class of 1921 [possibly 1971, 50th reunion]

It is located in an oversize folder in the map case. It is an oversize poster with pasted photographs of various Tufts people and activities, some are captioned, some are not. Poster 6: Four Photographs Photograph 1: Uncaptioned [Belly-dancing class] Photograph 2: Uncaptioned [Two players in Tufts v. Rhode Island soccer game] Photograph 3: Class on Consumer Products Evaluation Photograph 4: Sigma Nu Dance Marathon-1979

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
These dates are approximate. Some of these images may be in the Digital Library. This poster was found uncatalogued in the stacks in summer 2008. It is located in an oversize folder in the map case. It is an oversize poster with pasted photographs of various Tufts people and activities, some are captioned, some are not.
CAPTIONS: Poster 7: Nine Photographs (left to right, then top to bottom)
Photograph 1: Civil Engineering students doing what they have always done. Note their stocking caps. Probably taken in the 1920s.
Photograph 2: A Tufts Arena Theatre production circa 1940. Tall man in left center is the late John Holmes, A29, who wrote "Along the Row." [text written below the photograph: "Photos by Roger Whittmore (?)" and "Scene from 'The Male Animal'".]
Photograph 3: What appears to be rugby matches on the Oval, probably taken in the early 1900's [sic]. Note Metcalf Hall (with Tower!) in center background and old Jackson Gym on extreme left.
Photograph 4: The Kursaal, so named by the late President Carmichael. Located in Cousens Gym across the corridor from the current Athletics Office, it was equivalent in the late thirties and early forties to the Curtis Hall snack bar.
Photograph 5: Commencement procession, probably in the early forties.
Photograph 6: Track team, probably taken in the early 1940's. Coach "Ding" Dussault on left. Fellow next to him in striped jersey died overseas in World War II.
Photograph 7: Physical education classes - but when? Possibly the twenties or the thirties.
Photograph 8: Opera production probably staged in the old Goddard Gym, now the Fletcher School building.
Photograph 9: ROTC cadets on parade during WWII. The officer is Clarence P. Houston, WWI decorated officer, Director of Athletics at Tufts for many years, Professor of Business Law and first Vice President for Development (now called Resources). He was in charge of their military training on campus. He built Alumni House as his home

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These dates are approximate. Some of these images may be in the Digital Library. This poster was found uncatalogued in the stacks in summer 2008. It is located in an oversize folder in the map case. It is an oversize poster with pasted photographs of various Tufts people and activities, some are captioned, some are not. CAPTIONS: Poster 8: Four Photographs (left to right, then top to bottom) Photograph 1: Goddard Gym was built in 1883. The Fletcher School opened in 1932. Between these two dates all indoor physical education was carried on in this building. [first caption] Goddard Hall-Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy-Old Gymnasium. [second caption]. Photograph 2: Members of the faculty and administration, probably taken in the 1930s. Man at the extreme right is Professor Munro, who took thousands of photographs of the campus. (image in the DL-MS036:MS036.011.DO.01198) Photograph 3: Uncaptioned [Professor Leo Rich Lewis and unidentified man in fur coat] Photograph 4: Professor Leo Rich Lewis, composer of "Dear Alma Mater", at his desk. Well known eccentricity - filing everything on tiny scraps of paper in the numerous cubbyholes in his desk. (image in DL-MS036:MS036.011.DO.01136)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These dates are approximate. Some of these images may be in the Digital Library. This poster was found uncatalogued in the stacks in summer 2008. It is located in an oversize folder in the map case. It is an oversize poster with pasted photographs of various Tufts people and activities, some are captioned, some are not. CAPTIONS: Poster 9: Nine Photographs (left to right, then top to bottom) Photograph 1: 1959 Row of Trees. Only five years after the college opened! Photograph 2: Locomotive stopped for some obscure reason in gut along Boston Avenue. Note old-style police helmet on officer standing on locomotive steps on extreme left of picture. Photograph 3: Packard Hall 30 years after it was built. [Caption on photograph reads "Daniel Pratt at Tufts College in May, 1885"] (image in DL- UA136.002.DO.04676) Photograph 4: The old bell on the roof of Ballou Hall. It was used for all kinds of signaling purposes. (image in DL- MS054.003.DO.02459) Photograph 5: The Tufts campus in the earliest years. Note the reservoir on the right. The houses at the left face Professors Row and Curtis Street. The road in the foreground is Packard Avenue. Photograph 6: Photo taken from where Wessell Library now stands with Boston in the background. Photograph 7: Goddard Chapel with 1959 row of trees. Many trees were planted on the Tufts campus over the years. Many of these were destroyed in the 1938 hurricane. Photograph 8: Photo taken from where Mugar Hall now stands with Boston in the background. The white house (left center) is now Zeta Psi. Photograph 9: Men's singing group taken in the old Goddard Gymnasium (now the Fletcher School). Those beams are now hidden from sight unless you know what door to open to see a portion of them. Note gym apparatus in background. Photo taken in the 1920's [sic] or earlier.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These dates are approximate. Some of these images may be in the Digital Library. This poster was found uncatalogued in the stacks in summer 2008. It is located in an oversize folder in the map case. It is an oversize poster with pasted photographs of various Tufts people and activities, some are captioned, some are not. CAPTIONS: Poster 10: Eight Photographs (left to right, then top to bottom) Photograph 1: No Alumni Day for many years (up to the early 1940's) was ever complete without the presence of the Salem Cadet Band. One can get an idea of when this photo was taken by the car on the left. Photograph 2: The campus lawn was decorated with Japanese lanterns for Alumni Day. The Salem Cadet Band plays on the platform. Photograph 3: Probably Boston Red Sox Players in the early forties dropping pennies into Jumbos trunk for luck. The Red Sox for many years took early spring practice in Cousens Gym. Photograph 4: Alumni Day photo. The band was probably an authentic Navy band. Photo probably taken in the early 1920's. Photograph 5: The Alumni Day Luncheon on the campus lawn served under a huge tent. Most recent class identifiable is 1936. Probably taken in 1937. Photograph 6: Jumbo's preserved hide needed constant care. Every five or six years experts carefully worked on it to keep it from disintegrating. Photograph 7: Costumed members of the class of 1917 at an Alumni Day, perhaps in 1932. Photograph 8: Though only the stuffed remains of a once magnificent beast, Tufts' own Jumbo was loved not only by Tufts folks, but by school children who came to see him for miles around. This photo, probably taken in the late thirties, not only shows the size of Jumbo, but other stuffed animals in the background. Barnum at one time contained a large number of stuffed creatures, both animals and birds.

did.unittitle: Secretary of Alumni Assocation, Fred Nickless

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the files of the alumni secretary (now called director) of the Tufts University Alumni Association, Fred P. Nickless, files contain symposium pamphlets, correspondence files, committee files, some death reports of alumni, and a few alumni committee handbooks. This series contains alumni symposium pamphlets for 1967 and 1969, various committee files, the chronological correspondence files from 1971 to 1984, and the correspondences of the alumni office staff. These include the Sheetz and Tredennick correspondences. There are alumni committee handbooks and death reports of alumni in 1976 which are restricted. Fred Nickless took these files home from the alumni office upon his retirement in 1986; his daughter returned them in 2007 to the university.

scopecontent.p: Photographs found uncataloged in the stacks in the winter of 2009.

did.unittitle: Secretary of Alumni Assocation, Joseph W. Morton

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence and photographs from Joseph W. Morton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Included original photograph removed from frame.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by the Office of Alumni Relations, 2017, accession UA-2018-014.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in received order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains an alumni scrapbook, photographs of Tufts graduating classes, event brochures, event photographs, audio reels and cassettes, and powerpoints of presentations.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Due to the amount and nature of the digital files in this series, access to these files is provided through links to Tufts Box.

did.unittitle: Alumni Day and Commencement audio reel

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Donated to the Office of Alumni Relations in memory of of Tufts alumnus and volunteer Chapter Leader Robert Bartlett Hempstead A61 by his wife Sally Hempstead of Wethersfield, Connecticut.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file includes a Senior Banquet brouchure (1942), a directory (1956-1957), and the Junior Poetry Anthology (1959).

did.unittitle: Gregory Maguire in New York City cassette
Cape Cod Alumni Trip, Dean Norris

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains four photographs: East Hall, 1917; Military Company, 1917; drawing of Alumni House, undated; untitled and undated photograph of Tufts event, circa 1980s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in order of accession.

acqinfo.p: Transferred by the Office of Alumni Relations, 2018, accession UA-2019-019.
